Kinnera Priya Putti
A hypocrite with a deep appreciation of the beautiful horror of femininity. Fandom obsessed. And something extraordinaire, somewhere.
Apr 15

I once believed. And now I don’t.

“I love you.” He heard me.
“You don’t believe in love.” I heard him.
“You believe in love. I believe in you.”
And his heart burst into flames. The good kind, of course.

I didn’t know then that flames were indicative of a faulty piece. 
I didn’t know then that my heart had needed to sparkle too.
I didn’t know.

Anyway, our story doesn’t end the way it started.

Alone when together. 
Together when alone in the crowd.
Alone in that very crowd, that has only me and him. 
Just us.

I start to wonder how we ever reached this stage. How we got to this place in our lives where together is as tormenting as apart, where staying feels as if I’m being held to flame.

Holding hands now itches my hand to let go when once it ached to not. The fire used to race up my arm in a semblance of warmth and comfort, but it just burns its way through now, uncaring of the pain it causes me.

Looking at each other now digs up the worst of us when once the best was only then. I could watch the vibrancy in the burn before and be content, but I find myself waiting for the show now, the big reveal.

Looking away now begs to look back a little after I realise I don’t look at him anymore when once I just begged to not look away. I never needed to look up at the sky for validation before, but now I feel the need to see the fireworks burst through the sky and spell it out for me.

Well, I couldn’t see any other way of this mess.

He was the one who’d accidentally brushed past me at a convention. That slow smoulder he’d ignited had lit me from the inside.
He was one who’d dragged me along into this impossible world of a world alive. I’d have been happy in my little bubble of darkness when he’d burst in like a rocket on the Fourth of July.
He was the one who’d told me I was his mate. A soul-mate. The kind that lights the blaze and livens the sky. Supposedly. I’d told him love held no meaning for me, and that I was happy living in the dark, with only the stars to light the way for me.
He was the one who’d later decided I wasn’t the other half he’d envisioned he would get. He’d wanted more. More colourful. More spectacular. More his.
He was the one who’d took me to meet his family. I wasn’t what they wanted, they said, as though I was bought home from a retail store on the way home from work. They gave me less respect that he did. And he gave none. I suppose he agreed with them. Apparently, I needed to have been custom made for him, designed just to be his.
He was the one who’d told me forces choose soul mates in this world. I thought he was telling me we were destined, that our lives were designed to collide, to create a display never seen before. He seemed to have meant that the my firework was too ordinary to be associated with him. Maybe he figured I wouldn’t be adding to his magnificent display after all.

What if it wasn’t supposed to be so? But I ask myself this now, when I know the answer already.

He was the one who’d taken me to his stockpile of fireworks. His stash. Not ours. Never ours, he said. But the hoard of power had bonded to me like no one else could, as insane as it sounds. As if it said I was a part of it, like it was a part of me.

Power was a part of me. Like I was a part of him. Like he wasn’t a part of me.

So I’d found a way for him to get rid of me and find the blast he wanted.

I’d always thought people who gave up their love for loved ones were assuredly gone bonkers. I’d never understood. Till now. Until now.

I had told him I’d found a way for him to get rid of me and he’d had the bloody nerve to be affronted about it. Everyone else in our shared lives had let go, stepping away from the scene of the upcoming blast. He’d let me go then, like a snap that comes after the silence, the one you never expect. And my knees were scraped from falling to the ground one too many times, the ends too frayed to hold on to the flame. Drowning in my pity party to try and ignore all the aches and pains beginning to bog me down, I try to hold my edges together long enough for the fire to flay through.

Thank whoever the lord of this place is that he’s awake. Only one thing left to be done.

One thing to let him free. Free to find love. Love the way he wanted to love. Be loved the way he wanted to be loved.

All he had to do was fire me up.

Just tie me to one and let me free.
Let myself unveil the spectacle and flaunt the flamboyance I know I will be.

Kinnera Priya Putti exists. She identifies as a student in strictly technical terms. On weekdays and weekends, she writes and reads. She’s on Twitter @kinnerapriyap and is the current Ed Head of Kshitij- IITR’s LitMag.
If you mention HP or SPN to her, among other fandoms you may accidentally trigger, you will never leave!

Thanks to Aura Wilming.
